awd_titl_txt: Use of Rattus to Track Human Migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Research team members will collaborate to use island black rats as bioproxies to understand the history of human voyages across oceanic expanses. Through genetic investigation of species introduced to islands by human voyagers it should be possible to determine when they were introduced.

The research team is investigating the origin of long distance maritime movement using genomic analysis of invasive black rats. Recent advances in population genomics, specifically high-throughput genotyping of single base pair DNA changes, whole genome sequencing, and statistical estimation of demographic histories, have made it possible to infer the geographic origins and timing of rat introductions from contemporary samples. Such approaches will be used in this project to learn when, and from where, rats first reached an island setting. Establishing the antiquity of such rat populations will help archaeologists determine sites for future research. This project will significantly revise understanding of remote voyaging networks with all their transformative cultural, economic, and ecological impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed the use of black rats on the Chagos archipelago as a bioproxy to shed light on a longstanding historical mystery: when did ancient sailors first master the direct sea route across the Indian Ocean? Sometime between 1000 and 5000 years ago, sailors discovered they could cross the Indian Ocean directly by using monsoon winds, rather than following lengthy coastal routes. While this southern monsoon route between East Africa and Sri Lanka was known to ancient Greeks and Romans, debate continues about who first used it regularly. Traditional hypotheses suggest Arabian seafarers began using it around 1500 years ago, but some evidence hints at earlier use, possibly 2000-2200 years ago, which would reveal more extensive ancient trade networks than previously thought. Shipwrecks or ancient archaeological materials have yet to be discovered on the Chagos archipelago. In this study, we employed population genomic analyses of invasive black rats that were introduced to the Chagos by humans to identify potential early human use of the islands.

Black rats originated in southern Asia and spread globally through human travel relatively early, thus their presence on islands can reveal ancient shipping routes and trading patterns. The Chagos archipelago is particularly valuable for this research because it had no permanent human settlements before the late 18th century, making it an ideal location to study early maritime contact through the rats that may have arrived via shipwrecks or brief visits. To date, our genetic analysis of rats from ten islands in the Chagos archipelago has yielded several discoveries. Most rats across the archipelago share very similar mitochondrial genome sequences, suggesting they descended from a small founding population. However, rats on Ile des Rats show distinct genetic patterns, possibly representing a separate introduction. Intriguingly, these rats share close genetic similarities with 6th-century remains found at a Byzantine site in Serbia, suggesting unexpected historical connections. We also found that rats on Diego Garcia and the Maldives are genetically different from other Chagos populations, indicating separate introduction events. This pattern aligns with historical shipping routes and supports the idea of multiple periods of maritime activity in the region.

Mitochondrial DNA analyses could only reveal so much, however, because the Chagos rats have relatively low mitochondrial genetic variation and are a part of a black rat lineage that is found in many other places. To improve the resolution of our analyses, we also produced high-coverage whole genome sequences from 14 rats from eight of the Chagos islands. The genetic data generated by this project has substantially increased the genetic information available or black rats, a globally important invasive species. Analyses of the whole genome sequences are ongoing and will reveal much more about the geographical origins and timing of arrival of rats on the Chagos archipelago. This innovative research combines biology, history, and genomic technology to shed new light on ancient maritime trade routes. By studying these unwitting stowaways, we will improve our understanding of early global connections and human maritime achievement.
